item: Consider what is meant by acting with honesty and integrity toward patients and society, and behave accordingly (c.f. considering conflict of interest).
Consider what behaviors are expected of a member of a professional body in order to be trusted by society, and act accordingly.
Appropriately recognize one’s own limitations and act accordingly.
Accept feedback from others appropriately.
Treat others, including patients, with compassion.
Consider the causes and context when one fails to treat others compassionately.
Strive to understand others, recognizing the limits of one’s own imagination.
Consider and be aware of one’s own prejudices and those held as a group that may act as obstacles to understanding others, and act accordingly.
Consider what is meant by dignity and why it is expected of physicians, and strive to act accordingly.
Behave with courtesy.
Acquire an appropriately broad education that befits a physician’s deep involvement in people’s lives.
Continue to contemplate questions that have no definitive answers.
Understand an overview of ethical issues related to life and death.
Respect patients’ rights, including their right to make decisions for themselves, and collaborate with multidisciplinary professionals and understand diverse values.
Express one’s own opinions on ethical issues in medical practice, analyzing them using ethics-based concepts.
Understand medical issues from a comprehensive, transdisciplinary perspective.
Understand the importance of involving appropriate medical institutions and departments.

Use relevant core frameworks and heuristics (e.g., frequency, severity, urgency, anatomical approach, pathophysiological approach, dual process theory, prior probability) to perform clinical reasoning.
Conduct medical interviews, physical examinations, and tests as necessary for the patient’s presenting complaint.
Understand an overview of undiagnosed health problems and the appropriate methods of intervention.
Understand an overview of interventions for multiple co-morbidities and for diseases that affect multiple organs.
Understand an overview of polypharmacy and related interventions.
Understand comprehensive approaches to biopsychosocial problems.
Understand approaches that take into account the impact on both the individual and family.
Elicit individual patients’ medical expectations, explanatory models, and health perspectives.
Understand the impact of the patient’s social background (e.g., economic and health system-related aspects) on their illness.
Understand an overview of the effects of continuity of medical care (e.g., time, information, relationships).
List the five steps of EBM.
Define the clinical question using the PICO (PECO) framework (patient/population/problem, intervention (exposure), comparison, and outcome).
Search for evidence from secondary sources such as databases and clinical guidelines.
Critically appraise the obtained evidence.
Understand the different types of clinical practice guidelines, the strength of the recommendations made, and pitfalls in their use.
Consider the application of evidence to patient care taking into account the patient’s unique values and circumstances.
Apply knowledge, theories, and interviewing methods related to behavioral science to diagnosis, treatment, care, and prevention.
Recommend appropriate social support coordination and cognitive behavioral therapy as needed.
Apply behavioral economics to health care.
Assess holistic suffering (physical, psychosocial, and spiritual) through an understanding of the concept of palliative care.
Understand an overview of pharmacological and non-pharmacological palliative measures for somatic symptoms in patients with and without cancer.
Plan for the management of pain and distress in the acute care setting, with an understanding of the importance of communication with the patient and family members regarding end-of-life care.
Plan for the management of chronic diseases and chronic pain by understanding their pathophysiology, course, and treatment strategies.

Plan to support the patient and family members in a way that takes into account their suffering and concerns, including appropriate assistance toward balancing care and schooling, working, and parenting.
Understand local and community health disparities and appropriately assess healthcare system issues such as barriers to accessing medical care.
Understand the relevance of a patient’s geographic and cultural context to health.

Understand an overview of the current distribution of health care and physicians (regional, departmental, and clinical/non-clinical) in terms of the local context (including urban, suburban, remote areas, and remote islands).
Respond flexibly as a medical practitioner in a way that reflects the local medical system and the scale and function of its medical institutions.
Use indices such as incidence and prevalence of each disease in the area where the patient resides, and apply these in clinical reasoning.

Collect quantitative indicators (e.g., population composition) and qualitative information (geographical, historical, economic, and cultural contexts) for the community and explain local health issues.
Understand an overview of the significance of community health promotion activities undertaken in collaboration with local residents and healthcare professionals.
Propose medical care and services adapted to the local human and physical resources available.

Understand an overview of medical care delivery systems and systems for nursing care, health care, and welfare in situations with limited medical resources, such as remote islands, remote areas, and areas with a shortage of physicians.
Understand the necessity for and challenges related to home care in terms of its current status and how it is adapted to meet patients’ needs.
Understand an overview of the nature of home-based end-of-life care and its challenges.
Consider patient issues from the perspective of the life cycle (fetal, neonatal, infant, school-age, adolescent, young adult, mature adult, geriatric, and end-of-life stages).
Consider health management and environmental and lifestyle improvements from the perspective of life stages and life events.
Identify problems between patients and family members (abuse, neglect, etc.) from the perspective of the family life cycle, family member relationships, and family systems.
Understand physical and physiological development in childhood.
Understand normal psychomotor development in childhood.
Understand attachment formation, appropriate childcare methods, and nutrition in childhood.
Understand nutritional characteristics in childhood, and nutritional education.
Understand the relationship between the development of immune systems and infectious diseases in childhood.
Understand the current status of and problems relating to the transition of medical care from childhood to adulthood.
Understand physiological characteristics of fetal circulation and respiration and their changes at birth.
Understand the physiological characteristics of neonates and infants.
Understand the mechanisms of puberty and secondary sexual characteristic development.
Understand issues associated with school age and adolescence (such as those related to school, friends, etc.).
Understand issues related to adolescence and young adulthood (such as those related to reproduction, sanctity of life, etc.)
Understand issues related to adulthood (such as those related to mental health, work, exercise, infertility, etc.).
Understand the changes in organs and bodily functions associated with aging, their mechanisms, and the physiological changes that accompany these changes.
Perform a comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA).
Understand geriatric syndromes (gait disorders and falls, cognitive dysfunction, voiding disorders, nutritional disorders, feeding and swallowing disorders, etc.).
Understand the concepts of frailty, sarcopenia, and locomotive syndrome, how to deal with them, and how to prevent them.
Understand the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF).
Understand nutrition management for the elderly.
Understand the nursing care and environmental adjustments required for activities of daily living.
Understand the concept and definition of death and biological death.
Show consideration for the views on life and death held by the patient and their family members, applying one’s knowledge of the physical and mental processes that lead to death.
Understand end-of-life care.
Understand the special characteristics of pediatric end-of-life care.

Understand advanced care planning (ACP), compliance with advance directives, life-prolonging treatment, do-not-resuscitate instructions, death with dignity and euthanasia, and discontinuation and withholding of treatment.
Understand grief care.

Apply a comprehensive approach to health issues, using health-related knowledge, such as relevant definitions, healthy life expectancy, salutogenic theory, well-being, quality of life (QOL), social determinants of health (SDH), ICF, and universal health coverage (UHC), in building an understanding of the patient’s views on health and values regarding illness.
Explain the process that a patient goes through to receive medical care from a layperson’s perspective.

Evaluate an individual’s nutritional status on the basis of knowledge and statistical information on nutrition and energy metabolism, and plan appropriate dietary support that takes into account the lifestyle and values of the patient and family members.

Assess an individual’s daily activity on the basis of knowledge and statistical information related to physical activity and sports medicine and science, and plan support for activities and exercise that takes into account the lifestyle and values of the patient and family members.

Assess an individual’s rest and mental health on the basis of knowledge and statistical information, and plan support that takes into account the lifestyle and values of the patient and family members.

Evaluate and plan personal support on the basis of knowledge and statistical information about the health effects of smoking and drinking alcohol, taking into account the lifestyle and values of the patient and family members.
Understand an overview of SDH and health advocacy.
Consider the meaning of a person’s words and actions in the context of the person’s life history and social relationships.

Explain the relationship between patients and their families and their living environment, community, and medical institutions from the perspective of cultural anthropology and sociology (primarily medical anthropology and medical sociology).
Explain various phenomena related to a patient’s judgment and behavior using theories and concepts in cultural anthropology and sociology (primarily medical anthropology and medical sociology).
Access the best medical information currently available, recognizing that medical knowledge is being constantly updated.
Reflect on one’s learning and experience, and identify one’s own developmental needs.
Develop one’s career independently and proactively while cultivating one’s own professional values.
Take care of one’s physical and mental health.
Learn collaboratively with peers (including junior doctors and other colleagues).
Provide appropriate feedback to peers (including junior doctors and other colleagues).
Apply adult learning theory to educate peers (including junior doctors and other colleagues).
Question established theories.
Be intellectually curious about everything.
Be inspired by cutting-edge research.
Learn from senior researchers as role models.
Understand that the practice of medicine is based on research in basic medicine, clinical medicine, and social medicine.
Read medical articles (in English) and gain an outline understanding of their content.
Propose research questions based on one’s own interests.
Draft an outline research plan.
Acquire knowledge of fundamental experimental techniques from practical training in basic medicine.
Acquire knowledge of basic research methodology from practical training in social medicine (including behavioral science).
Acquire the ability to apply medical research techniques through laboratory experience, etc.
Record and manage research data appropriately.
Summarize one’s own research in the form of papers, reports, conference presentations, etc.
Present research contents in an easy-to-understand manner that is appropriate for the particular audience or readership.
Ask questions and express opinions in response to other researchers’ presentations.
Explain the types of research misconduct, including fabrication, falsification, plagiarism, etc., and refrain from committing research misconduct.
Understand and comply with important rules regarding research involving human subjects (including clinical trials for new drug/device application and specified clinical trials).
Understand and comply with important rules regarding conflicts of interest and animal and genetic modification experiments.
Understand an overview of cell observation methods.
Illustrate basic cell structure.

Understand an overview of the structure and function of the nucleus, ribosomes, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes and other cytomembrane systems, mitochondria, chloroplast, and cytoskeleton.
Understand an overview of the structure and function of cell membranes and cell–cell adhesion and binding patterns.
Understand the characteristics of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
Understand Mendelian laws, mitochondrial inheritance, epigenetic modification including imprinting, and multifactorial inheritance.
Understand the relationship between genotype and phenotype.
Understand the structure of chromosomes, the structure and relationship between genomes, chromosomes, and genes, and the behavior of chromosomes during somatic and meiotic divisions.
Understand the expression and regulation of genetic information (central dogma), including DNA replication and repair, transcription from DNA to RNA, and translation leading to protein synthesis.
Understand an overview of genomic analysis technologies including chromosome analysis and DNA sequencing.
Understand an overview of genome editing technologies and their applications.
Understand the basic concepts of evolution.
Understand biological species and their phylogenetic relationships.
Understand an overview of molecular phylogenetic trees on the basis of comparison of amino acid and nucleotide sequences.
Understand the ionic composition of intracellular and extracellular fluids and the mechanisms of osmotic pressure and (resting) membrane potential formation.
Understand ion channels, pumps, and active and passive transport processes of substances across the plasma membrane.

Understand the mechanisms of action potential generation and conduction, synaptic (including neuromuscular junction) morphology, and function (both excitatory and inhibitory) and plasticity of synaptic transmission.
Understand the types and functions of signal transduction.
Understand the types, subcellular localization, and functions of receptors, and their intracellular signaling processes.
Understand intracellular signal transduction by humoral factors (autocrine, paracrine, and endocrine).
Understand an overview of cytoskeletal proteins and their functions, and cell motility by the actin filament system.
Understand the processes of secretion and absorption across the plasma membrane, intracellular transport systems, and the role and function of microtubules.
Understand axonal transport, axonal degeneration, and regeneration.
Understand the structure and function of epithelial tissues and glands.
Understand the cells and intercellular matrix (fibrous components and matrix) that make up connective tissues.
Understand the microstructure and function of blood vessels and lymphatic vessels.
Understand the microstructure of nerve tissue.
Understand the structure and function of skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and smooth muscle.
Understand the mechanisms of tissue regeneration.

Understand positional relationships in directional terms (superior/inferior, anterior/posterior, medial/lateral, superficial/deep, cephalic/caudal, dorsal/ventral, proximal/distal, adduction/abduction).
Understand the types and mechanisms of organoleptic responses to stimuli.
Understand reflexes.
Understand homeostasis and adaptation of the body, and the regulatory mechanisms for homeostasis (feedback regulation).
Understand rhythmic changes in biological functions and the body’s internal environment.
Understand the importance of the interaction between commensal/intestinal bacteria and the host in maintaining homeostasis.
Understand an overview of the sequence of events from gametogenesis to birth, embryogenesis, and the process of intraembryonic body cavity formation.
Understand the formation and differentiation of body segments, differentiation of gill arch and gill sac, and the formation process of the head and neck, and the face and oral cavity.
Understand the formation process of the skeleton and muscles of the trunk and limbs, and the cardiovascular and urogenital systems.
Understand the formation process of the digestive and respiratory systems.
Understand neural tube differentiation and the formation process of the brain, spinal cord, visual organs, balance organs and autonomic nervous system, and skin.
Understand the function and regulation of enzymes.

Understand the structure, metabolism, and regulation of carbohydrates (glycolysis, tricarboxylic acid cycle, electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation, glycogen metabolism, gluconeogenesis, pentose phosphate pathway) and their physiological significance.
Understand protein structure, metabolism and regulation, physiological significance, metabolism of major amino acids, and the urea cycle.
Understand the structure, metabolism and regulation, physiological significance, and transport of lipids (lipoproteins).
Understand an overview of porphyrin and heme metabolism.
Understand the synthesis, catabolism, and recycling pathways of nucleotides.
Understand an overview of oxidative stress (free radicals, reactive oxygen species).
Understand the types and actions of vitamins and trace elements.
Understand the interconversion of nutrients and energy metabolism (including definition of energy, nutritional value in food, energy consumption, and estimated energy requirements).
Understand the metabolism when fasting, starving, after eating, overeating, and exercising.
Understand an overview of glycoconjugates and conjugated lipids.
Understand the differences in structure and function of bacteria as prokaryotes compared with eukaryotes.
Understand the mechanisms by which bacteria cause diseases by classifying the routes of bacterial infection.
Understand the mechanisms of action of protein toxins and non-protein toxins produced by bacteria.

Describe the bacteriological characteristics, risk factors, routes of infection, and pathogenesis of the major gram-positive cocci, gram-positive rods, gram-negative cocci, and gram-negative rods, and list the diseases they cause.
Explain the bacteriological characteristics, risk factors, routes of infection, and pathogenesis of acid-fast bacilli, and list the diseases they cause.
List the microbiological characteristics of spirochete, mycoplasma, rickettsia, and chlamydia and the diseases they cause.
Understand an overview of the bacteria that make up the microbiome and the functions of the microbiome in various parts of the body.
Classify viruses according to the structure and properties of viral particles.

Understand species specificity and tissue specificity of viral infections, their adsorption, invasion, replication, maturation, and release processes, and the changes that occur in virus-infected cells.
Describe the characteristics, risk factors, routes of infection, and pathogenesis of the major DNA viruses, and list the names of diseases caused by these viruses.
Describe the characteristics, risk factors, routes of infection, and pathogenesis of the major RNA viruses, and list the names of diseases caused by these viruses.

Describe the microbiological characteristics, risk factors, routes of infection, and pathogenesis of fungi (zygomycetes, ascomycetes, basidiomycetes, and imperfect fungi) and list the diseases they cause.

Understand the classification of parasites (protozoa and helminths), and the morphological characteristics, life cycle, risk factors, routes of infection and pathogenesis, infectious epidemiological significance, and characteristics of the biological defense of parasite-infected hosts.
Understand an overview of the mechanisms of action of antimicrobial agents with respect to the characteristics of microorganisms.
Understand the principles, types, and problems associated with vaccines against microbial infections.
Understand the life cycle, risk factors, routes of infection and pathogenesis, and epidemiological significance of microorganisms that cause zoonotic diseases.
Understand the life cycle, risk factors, transmission routes and pathogenesis, and epidemiological significance of microorganisms that cause vector-borne diseases.
Understand the tissues and cells involved in the immune response.
Understand how complement and innate immune cells are activated by pathogens and cause inflammation.
Understand the basic structure and function of major histocompatibility complex class I and class II molecules and the mechanism of T cell activation by antigen presentation.

Understand the mechanisms of diversity acquisition based on the structure and reaction patterns of immunoglobulins and T cell antigen receptors, and the structure and genetic reconstitution of immunoglobulin and T cell antigen receptor genes.
Understand the respective biological defense reactions for which helper T cells (Th1 cells, Th2 cells, and Th17 cells), cytotoxic T cells, and regulatory T cells are responsible.
Understand the mechanism of antibody production by B cell activation and the role of antibodies.
Understand the major cells that constitute the innate immune system and their activation mechanisms (TLRs, etc.).
Understand the types and roles of antigen-presenting cells and the mechanisms of antigen presentation.
Understand an overview of the characteristics of immune responses to viruses, bacteria, fungi, and parasites.
Understand an overview of primary and acquired immunodeficiency syndromes.
Understand the maintenance mechanisms of immune tolerance and the development of autoimmune diseases as a result of their breakdown.
Understand the mechanisms of allergic reactions.
Understand the cellular mechanisms involved in cancer immunity.
Understand the dose–response curve of drug/toxin reactivity for a living organism (or group of organisms).
Understand the relationship between receptor binding and pharmacological effects of drugs and agonists/antagonists.
Understand an overview of the adverse effects of drugs and drug–drug interactions.
Understand the diversity of individuals based on genomic diversity.
Understand single gene diseases, diseases caused by chromosomal aberrations, and diseases caused by mitochondrial gene mutations, including the mode of inheritance.
Understand the relationship between genetic and environmental factors in multifactorial diseases.
Understand an overview of the relationship between drug efficacy and safety, and genomic diversity.
Understand the diversity, etiology, and significance of cell injury/degeneration and cell death, including the difference between necrosis and apoptosis.
Understand the characteristics of cellular and tissue morphological changes in cell injury/degeneration and cell death.
Understand the pathogenesis of disorders of glucose metabolism.
Understand the pathogenesis of abnormal protein and amino acid metabolism.
Understand the pathogenesis of abnormal lipid metabolism.
Understand the pathogenesis of abnormal nucleic acid and nucleotide metabolism.
Understand the pathogenesis of abnormal vitamin and trace element metabolism.
Understand an overview of the pathogenesis of metabolic syndrome.

Understand the differences between hemodynamic disorders (inhibition, hypoxemia, hyperemia, stasis, hemorrhage) and their respective etiologies and pathogeneses, and the types and pathogeneses of infarction (thrombus, embolus).
Understand abnormal blood pressure (hypertension, hypotension).
Understand the definition of inflammation.
Understand the classification of inflammation, and its histomorphological and temporal changes (local and systemic).
Understand the healing process of inflammatory tissues.
Understand inflammation and its relationship with metabolic syndrome, atherosclerosis, neoplasm, and aging.
Understand autonomous growth and the difference between benign and malignant tumors.
Understand an overview of the various causes of cancer, including genetic changes.
Understand the terms dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, advanced carcinoma, early-stage carcinoma, atypia, and polymorphism.
Understand an overview of pathological diagnosis of cancer and its contribution to treatment.
Understand an overview of the mechanisms of cancer metastasis.
Understand an overview of the mechanisms of cancer elimination by the immune system.
Understand organ-specific and systemic diseases ([@tbl:TBL0100]).
Understand the basic structure and function of the blood and hematopoietic and lymphatic systems.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the blood and hematopoietic and lymphatic systems.
Understand the basic examination methods of the blood and hematopoietic and lymphatic systems.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the blood and hematopoietic and lymphatic systems.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the blood and hematopoietic and lymphatic systems.
Understand the basic structure and function of the nervous system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the nervous system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the nervous system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the nervous system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the nervous system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the dermatological system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the dermatological system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the dermatological system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the dermatological system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the dermatological system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the musculoskeletal system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the musculoskeletal system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the musculoskeletal system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the musculoskeletal system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the musculoskeletal system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the cardiovascular system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the cardiovascular system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the cardiovascular system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the cardiovascular system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the cardiovascular system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the respiratory system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the respiratory system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the respiratory system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the respiratory system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the respiratory system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the digestive system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the digestive system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the digestive system.
Understand specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the digestive system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the digestive system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the renal and urinary system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the renal and urinary system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the renal and urinary system.
Understand the specific treatments methods of diseases affecting the renal and urinary system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the renal and urinary system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the reproductive system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the reproductive system.
Understand the basics examination methods of the reproductive system.
Understand the specific treatment methods for diseases affecting the reproductive system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the reproductive system.
Understand the basic structures and functions associated with pregnancy and delivery.
Understand the symptoms associated with pregnancy and delivery.
Understand the basic examination methods for pregnancy and delivery.
Understand the specific treatment methods associated with pregnancy and delivery.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases associated with pregnancy and delivery.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases affecting children.
Understand the basic examination methods used in pediatrics.
Understand the specific treatment methods used in pediatrics.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of pediatric diseases and conditions.
Understand the basic structure and function of the breast.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the breast.
Understand the basic examination methods of the breast.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the breast.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the breast.
Understand the basic structure and function of the endocrine, nutritional, and metabolic systems.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the endocrine, nutritional, and metabolic systems.
Understand the basic examination methods of the endocrine, nutritional, and metabolic systems.
Understand the specific treatments of diseases affecting the endocrine, nutritional, and metabolic systems.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the endocrine, nutritional, and metabolic systems.
Understand the pathogenesis of metabolic syndrome.
Understand the basic structure and function of the ocular and visual system.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the ocular and visual system.
Understand the basic examination methods of the ocular and visual system.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the ocular and visual system.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the ocular and visual system.
Understand the basic structure and function of the ear, nose, throat, and oral cavity.
Understand the symptoms seen in diseases of the ear, nose, throat, and oral cavity.
Understand the basic examination methods of the ear, nose, throat, and oral cavity.
Understand the specific treatment methods of diseases affecting the ear, nose, throat, and oral cavity.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the ear, nose, throat, and oral cavity.
Understand the basic structure and function of the brain and mental system.
Understand the symptoms seen in psychiatric disorders.
Understand the basic examination methods used in psychiatry.
Understand the specific treatment methods of psychiatric disorders.
Understand the etiology, epidemiology, symptoms, examination, diagnosis, and treatment of psychiatric disorders.
Understand an overview of the Hardy–Weinberg law as a basis for population genetics.
Create and evaluate a family tree.
Understand the difference between germline and somatic mutations, and the purpose and significance of genetic testing.
Understand the characteristics of genetic information (constancy, predictability, shareability, and ambiguity).
Understand the significance and methods of genetic counseling.
Understand ethical, legal, and social considerations in genetic medicine.
Access information related to genetic medicine.
Understand an overview of appropriate approaches including treatment and prevention based on genetic information for patients with genetic disorders and asymptomatic family members.

Understand the concepts of and differentiate between collagen diseases, vasculitis, rheumatic diseases, allergic diseases, and autoimmune diseases, and list the specific diseases included in each category ([@tbl:TBL0100]).
Understand the signs and symptoms of collagen diseases, vasculitis, rheumatic diseases, allergic diseases, and autoimmune diseases ([@tbl:TBL0217]).
Understand the principles of immunoserological testing and the clinical significance of test results ([@tbl:TBL0217]).
Understand the therapeutic agents used in collagen diseases, vasculitis, rheumatic diseases, allergic diseases, and autoimmune diseases ([@tbl:TBL0217]).

Explain the etiology, epidemiology, syndromes, major tests/diagnoses, treatments, and complications relating to collagen diseases, vasculitis, rheumatic diseases, allergic diseases, and autoimmune diseases ([@tbl:TBL0217]).
Understand the causative microorganisms of common community-acquired infections.
Understand the causative microorganisms of common healthcare-associated infections.
Understand an overview of the common microorganisms that immunocompromised patients are susceptible to.
Understand the current status of drug resistance, common drug-resistant organisms (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), and preventive measures such as proper use of antimicrobial agents.
Understand the relationships between and among the patient (host), the organ/site of infection, and the causative microorganisms.
Understand the risk factors, routes of infection/entry sites, and pathophysiology of common community-acquired infections.
Understand the risk factors, routes of infection/entry sites, and pathophysiology of common healthcare-associated infections.
Understand the difference between sepsis and bloodstream infection, and their respective pathogeneses.
Understand the routes of transmission of emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, and understand the required infection control measures.
Understand and surmise the organs affected and microorganisms involved by taking a medical history and conducting appropriate physical examinations.
Understand how to diagnose causative microorganisms on the basis of history-taking and physical examination.
Understand standard laboratory tests (such as two sets of blood cultures, urinalysis/urine culture, and chest X-ray) for patients with fever.

Understand the principles of antimicrobial therapy (culture specimens should be submitted prior to antimicrobial administration, standard drugs should be selected in accordance with the relevant microorganisms and organs, and the duration of administration should be set).
Understand empirical antimicrobial therapy (presumptive therapy).
Understand specific antimicrobial therapy (targeted therapy).
Understand vaccine-preventable diseases ([@tbl:TBL0100]).
Understand occupational health (vaccination, needlestick injuries and body fluid exposure, tuberculosis exposure, etc.).

Understand the pathogenic microorganisms for which standard precautions and isolation precautions (droplet, contact, airborne, etc.) are required, the personal protective equipment and vaccinations necessary to prevent healthcare workers being exposed to pathogenic microorganisms from patients, and infection control measures following healthcare workers being exposed to bodily fluids.
Understand the definition of cancers and neoplastic diseases and their characteristics, along with genomic abnormalities and molecular mechanisms such as epigenetic modifications.
Understand the frequency at which the various types of cancer occur, both in Japan and internationally.

Understand risk factors such as genetic predisposition, underlying diseases, infectious diseases, and environmental and lifestyle factors for the development of neoplastic diseases, as well as cancer prevention and screening.
Understand an overview of cancer-specific tests and their findings, such as tumor markers, biomarkers, and cancer gene panel tests.
Understand and diagnose abnormal findings in endoscopy and imaging tests (X-ray, CT, MRI, PET/nuclear medicine, ultrasound, etc.) for tumors.
Understand an overview of biopsy, cytology, and pathological examinations of tumors and their findings.
Understand an overview of TNM classification and the staging system of cancers.
Understand the symptoms of patients with cancer ([@tbl:TBL0219]).
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major hematopoietic cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major brain tumors.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major skin cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major bone and soft tissue cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major thoracic (respiratory) cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major gastrointestinal cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major urologic cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major cancers of the reproductive system.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major breast cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major endocrine system cancers.
Understand the symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of major head and neck cancers.
Understand the major types, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of pediatric cancers.
Understand an overview of the types, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of cancers of unknown primary, and metastatic, overlapping, adolescent and young adult (AYA), and rare cancers.

Understand an overview of cancers prone to oncological emergencies (spinal cord compression, tumor lysis syndrome, superior vena cava syndrome, metabolic disorders, adverse treatment events, etc.) and their respective pathophysiologies, symptoms, and management.
Understand an overview of surgical treatment of major tumors.
Understand an overview of indications for radiation therapy and interventional radiology for major tumors.
Understand an overview of indications for pharmacotherapy (cytotoxic anticancer agents, molecular targeted agents), hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, and cancer immunology for major tumors.
Understand supportive and palliative care for patients with cancer.
Understand the social and psychological challenges for patients with cancer.

Understand an overview of the regional emergency medical care system through the concepts of the prehospital emergency medical care system, medical control, and primary, secondary, and tertiary emergency care.

Understand the pathogeneses of and main diagnostic criteria for the following shock categories: (1) distributive shock (anaphylactic, septic, neurogenic); (2) hypovolemic shock (hemorrhagic, fluid loss); (3) cardiogenic shock (myocardial contractility, valve disease, arrhythmia); and (4) obstructive shock (cardiac tamponade, pulmonary embolism, tension pneumothorax).
Understand the initial management for patients with shock and specific treatment depending on the cause of the shock.

Understand the pathogeneses of and main diagnostic criteria for the following causes of cardiac arrest: (1) cardiovascular (acute myocardial infarction, acute aortic dissection, ruptured aortic aneurysm, pulmonary embolism); (2) respiratory (airway obstruction, tension pneumothorax, hypoxemia due to parenchymal lesions); (3) neurogenic (severe head and spinal trauma, acute subarachnoid hemorrhage); (4) poisoning and environmental factors (poisoning, heat stroke, hypothermia); and (5) electrolyte and acid-base imbalance (hypo- and hyperkalemia, acidosis, hypoglycemia).
Understand the initial management of cardiac arrest (cardiopulmonary resuscitation and advanced cardiac life support) and specific treatments depending on its causes.
Surmise the substance responsible for poisoning the patient from their medical history and physical examination, on the basis of the toxidrome presented.
Understand an overview of the indications and contraindications for the use of absorption inhibitors, elimination accelerators, and antagonists in the treatment of poisoned patients.

Understand the etiology (pathogenesis), symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment of poisoning associated with food, gas (carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, cyanide), pesticide (organophosphorus, organochlorine), alcohol, and drugs (sleeping pills, psychotropic drugs, antipyretic analgesics, narcotics, stimulants).
Understand poisoning by mercury, lead, cyanide, arsenic, paraquat, natural poisons, corrosives (acids, alkalis, hydrogen fluoride), and accidental ingestion of button/coin batteries.
Understand the symptoms, major examinations, diagnoses, and treatment of disorders caused by high temperatures (heat stroke) and low temperatures (hypothermia)
Understand the symptoms, major examinations and diagnoses, and treatment of disorders caused by air pressure, vibration, and noise.
Understand the pathogenesis of and main diagnostic criteria for trauma.
Understand how to assess the severity of burns (presence/absence of airway burns, burn area and depth) and treatment strategies.
Understand organ failure (multiple organ failure, cytokine storm, and disseminated intravascular coagulation).
Understand intensive care and intensive care units.
Understand the biological invasions and reactions that occur in invasive procedures (i.e., surgery, trauma, burns, etc.).
Understand the conditions that require mechanical ventilation, extracorporeal membrane oxygen, assisted circulation, and acute blood purification therapy, and their significance.
Understand temperature management (including therapeutic temperature management) and nutritional management for critically ill patients.
Understand the concept of post-intensive care syndrome.
Understand the types of radiation, radioactivity, and an overview of their properties, quantification methods, and units.
Understand an overview of internal and external radiation exposure, dose management, and its pathogenesis, symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment.
Understand the effects (both acute and delayed) of radiation and electromagnetic waves on the human body (including the fetus), and how to use them appropriately.
Understand the differences in radiation permeability and radiosensitivity of various normal tissues.
Understand the characteristics of magnetic fields and electromagnetic waves used in MRI and understand adverse events such as heat generation in the human body and implanted metallic devices.

Understand the three fundamental principles of radiological protection in medical and occupational exposure, and safety management, and implement dose reduction in examinations and therapies that use radiation (X-ray, CT, nuclear medicine, angiography, interventional radiology, fluoroscopy, etc.).
Understand and determine the effects, costs, risks (e.g., radiation dose, acute and delayed effects), and indications of radiological examinations, including angiography and interventional radiology.
Understand the biological principles of radiotherapy, effects of radiation on genes and cells, the mechanisms of radiation-induced cell death, and local and systemic effects.
Understand the importance and social significance of using information science and technology in medicine.
Understand an overview of the regulations, laws, and guidelines related to information science and technology in medicine.
Discuss ethical issues, such as social disparities caused by the digital divide, that may arise in the use of information science and technology in medicine.

Understand the principles of medical data management and storage, including electronic medical records, and comply with relevant regulations, laws, ethical standards, and provisions for protecting personal information.
Understand and practice appropriate use of social media as a healthcare professional.
Use digital devices, such as PCs and smartphones, to make use of information science technology, such as the internet and apps, in medical practice.
Solve problems using the information and data collected using information science and technology.

Understand information science and technology related to medical care (medical information systems, wearable devices, applications, artificial intelligence, telemedicine technology, and the Internet of Things [IoT]) and discuss their potential applications.
Understand the role required of medical professionals when applying information science and technology to medical care by working together with relevant specialists.
Demonstrate effective documentation and use of features unique to electronic medical records.
Understand the pros and cons of remote communications, and select and use appropriate tools (e-mail, video conference systems, and social media) according to the intended purpose.
Use appropriate digital devices and applications (e-learning, mobile technology, etc.) for self-learning and cooperative learning.
Develop flexibility in using new information science and technology in one’s own learning and medical practice.
Use basic communication skills in medical interviews.

Establish the patient’s medical history (presenting complaint, history of present illness, medications, allergies, past medical history, family history, preferences, lifestyle, social and occupational history, living environment, home situation, travel history, and review of systems) via a medical interview, and select and organize the information obtained.
Obtain necessary information from people close to the patient.
Perform a medical examination according to the patient’s condition.
Assess general appearance (body shape, nutrition, posture, gait, facial features, skin, and speech).
Check vital signs (temperature, pulse, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation).
Examine the patient in appropriate positions (standing, sitting, Fowler’s, supine, and lithotomy position).
Perform physical examinations for each part of the body ([@tbl:TBL0300]).
Perform necessary basic medical examinations for each medical specialty ([@tbl:TBL0400]).
Gather appropriate patient information and produce a problem-oriented medical record.
Document the clinical course in terms of subjective findings, objective findings, assessment, and planning.
Summarize the past medical history in the medical record.
Understand the causes and pathophysiology of major symptoms ([@tbl:TBL0500]).
Consider and discuss differential diagnosis of major symptoms ([@tbl:TBL0500]) and explain the main diagnostic criteria.
Demonstrate clinical reasoning and make diagnostic inferences on the basis of the presenting complaint in the basic medical departments/specialties ([@tbl:TBL0400]).
Understand the basic pathogenesis and epidemiology of diseases in the basic medical departments/specialties ([@tbl:TBL0400]).

Understand the purpose and significance of major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600]), select the minimum number of tests required to verify the diagnostic hypothesis, and interpret the results.
Understand the correct methods of specimen collection and storage for major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600]).
Understand how to perform major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600]) in a safe manner (patient and specimen verification, test complications, infection prevention, and accuracy control).

Understand the characteristics (sensitivity, specificity, false positives, false negatives, pretest and posttest probability, likelihood ratio, receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve) and criteria (reference value, reference range, cutoff value, panic value) of major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600])
Understand physiological variability, measurement error, accuracy control, and human error in major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600]).
Understand patient-specific clinical characteristics and interpret results.
Understand and interpret the purpose and indications for major clinical and imaging tests ([@tbl:TBL0600]).
Plan initial response to major symptoms ([@tbl:TBL0500]) and consider whether specialist medical care is required.
Understand the basics of taking medication and adherence.
Draft prescriptions.
Understand the pharmacological effects of medications, and their indications, adverse events, and precautions to be taken when administering them.
Understand the key points of drug administration with regard to pharmacokinetic characteristics related to age and organ failure.
Understand pharmacokinetic interactions.
Understand contraindications and the use of drugs under specific conditions (e.g., anti-doping).
Understand the major drug allergy symptoms, diagnosis, prophylaxis, and management.
Understand drug accumulation, tolerance, tachyphylaxis, and dependence.
Understand the indications, adverse events, and precautions for the administration of anticancer agents.
Understand the pharmacological actions, indications, adverse events, and dosing precautions for antimicrobial agents.
Understand the indications, adverse events, and administration precautions for opioid analgesics and sedatives.
Understand an overview of the pharmacological actions and adverse events of molecular targeted drugs and biopharmaceuticals.
Understand an overview of the characteristics of Chinese medicine, indications of major Japanese and Chinese herbal medicines (Kampo medicine), and their pharmacological actions.
Understand an overview of indications for radiotherapy.
Understand an overview of interventional radiology.
Understand an overview of the indications for treatments using endoscopy.
Understand an overview of the indications for treatments using ultrasound.
Understand the types, indications, and effects of medical coatings.
Understand the indications and complications of surgical procedures.
Understand the risk factors of surgery and basic principles of risk management.
Understand the major postoperative complications and the basic principles of prevention.
Understand the importance of informed consent for surgery and invasive procedures.
Understand preoperative risk assessment.
Understand perioperative medication management and risk.
Understand perioperative fluid and blood transfusions.
Understand perioperative pain management.
Understand an overview of the indications, contraindications, and complications of local anesthesia, peripheral nerve block, plexus block, spinal anesthesia, and epidural anesthesia.
Understand an overview of preoperative assessment for safe management of anesthesia.
Understand an overview of patient monitoring during anesthesia, and major abnormal findings and how to manage them.
Understand the various types of anesthetics and muscle relaxants, and the principles of their use.
Understand the indications, contraindications, methods, accidents, and complications of inhalation and intravenous anesthesia.
Understand airway management techniques, including tracheal intubation.
Understand nutritional assessment, care, and management, the role of nutrition support teams, and nutritional therapies for specific diseases.
Understand the indications, methods, and complications of parenteral and enteral nutrition, and precautions for long-term administration.
Understand an overview of the major types of medical devices and their principles of operation.
Understand an overview of the major types and principles of artificial organs.
Understand the types and indications of blood products and fractionated plasma products.
Understand adverse reactions to blood transfusions, transfusion record-keeping requirements, and procedures to prevent incompatible blood transfusions.
Understand appropriate use of blood transfusion, component transfusion, autologous transfusion, and emergency transfusion.
Understand an overview of transplantation medicine (organ transplantation, tissue transplantation, hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, etc.) and how it is practiced both in Japan and overseas.
Understand an overview of the principles of discussing organ and tissue donation options in end-of-life care.
Understand immune response in transplantation (rejection, graft-versus-host disease).
Understand an overview of immunosuppressive therapy after transplantation.
Understand the concept and indications for rehabilitation.
Assess functional impairment and activities of daily living.
Understand an overview of physiotherapy, occupational therapy, and speech-language-hearing therapy.
Understand an overview of the major walking aids, wheelchairs, prostheses (artificial limbs and feet), and orthotics.
Develop a basic treatment plan for medical conditions in the basic medical departments/specialties ([@tbl:TBL0400]).
Formulate plans for patient education in major diseases.
Perform basic clinical procedures related to investigation ([@tbl:TBL0700]).
Perform basic clinical procedures related to treatment ([@tbl:TBL0700]).
Recognize patients who are in a critical condition on the basis of vital and physical signs.
Perform basic life support.
Assist in performing initial response (including advanced life support) for common critical conditions.
Assist in the initial response to trauma.
Assist in the response to anaphylactic shock.
Draft various types of medical certificates and patient referral documents.
Draft various certificates of postmortem examination.
Understand how to consult with other basic medical departments/specialties ([@tbl:TBL0400]).
Understand the prevention, evaluation, and treatment of pressure ulcers.
Present appropriately at clinical conferences and case review meetings.
Report information obtained from medical consultations and examinations to senior physicians in a clear and concise manner.
Participate in morbidity and mortality (M&M) conferences and express one’s own opinions.
Participate in clinico-pathological conferences (CPC) and express one’s own opinions.
Understand the importance of improving medical care using quality improvement methods, and acquire a focus on continuous evaluation and improvement.

Practice the health management (lifestyle improvements, vaccination, measures to reduce radiation exposure) and occupational infection control (tuberculosis screening, vaccination) measures expected of medical professionals.
Understand the need to improve the working environment for all healthcare professionals, including oneself, and strive to make such improvements.
Understand an overview of the management system for patient safety and the roles within the system (risk manager, patient safety management committee, etc.).
Understand criminal and civil liability related to medical errors and administrative penalties under the Medical Practitioners’ Act (July 30, 1948).

Understand the role and significance of systems related to healthcare-associated infections (hospital infection control committee, nosocomial infection surveillance, infection control team, infection control manual, etc.), and participate in those systems.
Explain the need for and practice standard precautions.
Respond appropriately when encountering a needlestick accident or exposure to bodily fluids.
Practice basic precautions (patient identification, double-checking, checklist method, alerting patients to drugs with similar names, fail-safe/fail-proof concepts, etc.).
Share information on patient safety (adverse drug reactions, drug-related accidents, medical errors, what not to do, good practice, etc.) and analyze the information for post-procedural use.
Understand and act on the importance of patient safety management for individuals and organizations.
Understand the importance of medical records, and document and handle them appropriately.
Respond to inquiries with sincerity.
Respond to, record, and report medical incidents[1] when they occur.
Demonstrate verbal communication skills to build good relationships.
Demonstrate awareness of nonverbal communication (professional appearance, eye contact, facial expressions, gestures, etc.).
Be respectful with language and in attitude when interacting with patients and family members.
Communicate with awareness of the psychological factors (positive and negative emotions, etc.) involved in interpersonal relationships.
Listen to patients and their family members, and state facts and express opinions in a way that they can understand.
Show full consideration of the mental, physical, and social distress and suffering that patients and their family members are experiencing.
Listen closely to patients and their family members, and understand and show empathy toward their feelings, such as anger, sadness, and anxiety.

Communicate with consideration for the diversity of patients and their family members (elderly, children, disabled, LGBTQ, nationality, race, and cultural, linguistic, and customary differences, etc.).
Explain concepts in simple terms, using as little jargon as possible to help patients to understand more easily.
Share information and opinions with patients and their family members, and support decision-making based on understanding and consent.
Understand issues that hinder patients’ self-decision-making.
Respect the patient’s experience and listen to them attentively so that they can make their beliefs and values clear.
Explain the best available evidence in an easy-to-understand manner, using as little jargon as possible to support patient decision-making.
Plan a treatment plan based on goals consistent with the patient’s values.
Assess the patient’s psychological and social background and their needs for independent living.
Identify and organize issues and problems that the patient may have.
Gather necessary information from the patient’s proxy, representative, or guardian when no information can be obtained from the patient.
Communicate with the patient from the viewpoint of family and community.
Participate in medical treatment that takes into account psychological and social backgrounds.
Understand the uncertainties inherent in medicine, and demonstrate the appropriate actions and attitude.
Share information related to patients and families with students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Explain, respond, and ask questions with respect for the roles and opinions of students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Refer and consult with appropriate facilities, specialties, and physicians for appropriate diagnosis, testing, and treatment.
Share ideas and expectations among physicians to ensure continuity of patient care and physician accountability.
Communicate one’s knowledge and values to students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Fulfill one’s own role among students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Learn and develop together with students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Understand concepts related to interpersonal relationships and interpersonal behavior.
Explain the role of the physician to students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Relate one’s own values, words, and actions to those of students of other disciplines and medical faculties.
Understand the roles of other professions according to their work environment (hospital, clinic, care facility, etc.) or other affiliations (team, department, etc.).
Understand the concept of public health.
Understand the concept of cohesive and connected society.
Understand the stages of prevention and their strategies.
Contribute to public health activities (health checkups, health promotion events, etc.) and understand their significance.
Understand the significance and overview of basic human rights related to health (e.g., the right to life) and social security (social insurance, social welfare, and public assistance.)
Discuss ideas for improving social insurance, including pension, long-term care, and medical insurance as universal health coverage, understanding their structures and problems.

Understand an overview of welfare for people with disabilities, including relevant laws such as the Act on Providing Comprehensive Support for the Daily Life and Life in Society of Persons with Disabilities (June 27, 2012).
Understand the roles of public health centers, community and municipal health centers, and regional institutes for hygienic and environmental sciences.
Understand the significance and outline of health promotion measures such as the Health Promotion Act (August 2, 2002) and promotion of good nutrition, physical activity, rest, etc.
Understand fundamental systems and laws related to community health.
Understand the significance of mental health and welfare for people with mental disabilities, and related systems and laws.

Understand the significance and outline of maternal and child health measures, including relevant laws such as the Basic Law for Child and Maternal Health and Child Development (December 14, 2018), Maternal and Child Health Law (August 18, 1965), Maternal Health Act (July 13, 1948), Child Welfare Act (December 12, 1947), and Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (May 24, 2000).
Understand the significance and outline of school health, including the School Health and Safety Act (May 10, 1958), the role of school physicians, and infectious disease in schools.
Understand the basic concept of occupational health, including its significance and the three pillars of management (working environment management, work practice management, and health management).
Understand fundamental systems and laws related to occupational and environmental health.
Understand occupational accidents and occupational diseases and their countermeasures.
Understand industrial poisoning caused by hazardous substances and its countermeasures.
Understand the concept and types of health crises and how to respond to them (including risk communication).
Understand fundamental systems and laws related to health crisis management (contingencies for emergencies such as infectious diseases, radiation accidents, and disasters).
Understand the significance of disaster health care, including disaster base hospitals and various activity teams.

Understand major demographic statistics (static and dynamic populations) and classifications and statistics of diseases and disabilities (such as the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems [ICD]).
Explain average life expectancy and healthy life expectancy.
Understand the roles of epidemiology from public health and clinical perspectives.
Understand the difference between proportions, ratios, and rates and typical epidemiological indicators (e.g., prevalence, risk ratios, incidence rates).
Give examples of major biases and confounding.
Explain the difference between direct and indirect methods in age-adjustment.
Understand the main epidemiologic study designs: observational (descriptive, cross-sectional, case-control, cohort) and interventional (randomized controlled trials, etc.).
Understand epidemiologic approaches specific to acute infectious diseases.
Support stakeholders in making decisions that have an impact on the population while taking into account the limitations of the evidence.
Describe scales (interval, ratio, ordinal, nominal).
Explain the distribution of data (including missing values).
Explain confidence intervals for the population mean of a normal distribution.
Perform correlation analysis, statistical tests (mean, proportion), etc.
Understand the significance of multivariate analysis.
Understand vegetative state, brain death, cardiac death, and determination of brain death.
Understand how to handle unusual deaths and coroner’s inquests.
Prepare death certificates or certificates of postmortem examination.
Understand forensic identification methods.
Understand pathological autopsy and forensic autopsy (judicial autopsy, administrative autopsy, death investigation and identification autopsy, and autopsy with consent.)
Support people to extend their healthy life expectancy.
Act with an understanding of concepts related to disability and social environments, such as barrier-free access.
Work proactively to eliminate gender inequality, such as discrimination against women and the LGBTQ community.
Understand the relationship between climate change and health care, and envisage how health issues facing patients could be associated with climate change.
Understand the role of physicians when natural disasters occur, including the spread of emerging infectious diseases.
Understand an overview of the concepts and terminology in contemporary thought and philosophy.
Relativize contemporary medical issues, reflecting on the historical evolution and transition of medicine and medical practice.
Understand the influence of economics on medical practice.
Describe one’s opinion, considering what equity is in distributing health care resources.
Understand the professional rights and duties of physicians as defined by the Medical Practitioners’ Act (July 30, 1948).
Explain the laws and systems governing the medical profession.
Understand the types and functions of medical institutions defined by the Medical Care Act (July 30, 1948).
Understand an overview of medical care plans (as defined by the Medical Care Act).
Understand an overview of how problems in regional medical care delivery are related to each other.
Express one’s own opinions about the medical care delivery system and the way physicians work.
Understand an overview of medical and health issues in global health, including their historical and social contexts.
Understand the significance of universal health coverage, and give examples of problems faced by health care systems around the world.
Understand an overview of health-related United Nations development goals and international organizations and groups involved in international collaboration in global health.

Explore the ways patients perceive health, illness, and death in various situations, including in their daily lives and in healthcare settings such as outpatient/inpatient care, home care, and nursing care.
Understand and explain the structure of phenomena related to medical practice with respect to historical trends, social circumstances, and relevant systems.
Understand the influence of culture and customs on individuals and groups (e.g., methods of communication).
